priority: Phase 3 - Expansion (Orphan Indication with RCT Evidence)

studies.study_title: THC for Tourette Syndrome: First Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Müller-Vahl KR, Schneider U, Koblenz A, et al. 2002. Pharmacopsychiatry.
studies.title: THC for Tourette Syndrome: First Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Müller-Vahl KR, Schneider U, Koblenz A, et al.

outcomes.results: THC: Tic frequency reduced 35%; Tic severity reduced 41% (p<0.05); Global impression improved in 11/12 patients
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: No cognitive impairment; OCD symptoms improved; mood stable

safety.adverse_events: Mild: dizziness, fatigue; No serious AEs

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - First RCT in Tourette syndrome; established cannabinoid efficacy for tics

studies.study_title: THC for Tourette Syndrome: 6-Week Treatment Trial
studies.citation: Müller-Vahl KR, Schneider U, Prevedel H, et al. 2003. Neuropsychopharmacology.
studies.title: THC for Tourette Syndrome: 6-Week Treatment Trial
studies.authors: Müller-Vahl KR, Schneider U, Prevedel H, et al.

outcomes.results: THC: YGTSS reduced by 35% vs Placebo: 8% (p<0.01); Significant sustained tic reduction over 6 weeks
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: OCD symptoms: 42% improvement; Premonitory urges reduced; Quality of life improved 38%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - 6-week sustained efficacy; YGTSS validated endpoint; gold-standard RCT

studies.study_title: Nabiximols for Tourette Syndrome: Phase II Trial (CANNA-TICS)
studies.citation: Müller-Vahl KR, Fremer C, Beez T, et al. 2021. Movement Disorders.
studies.title: Nabiximols for Tourette Syndrome: Phase II Trial (CANNA-TICS)
studies.authors: Müller-Vahl KR, Fremer C, Beez T, et al.

outcomes.results: Nabiximols: TTS reduced 14.0 vs Placebo: 5.6 (p=0.003); Highly significant; Effect maintained at 13 weeks
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: YGTSS improved; premonitory urges reduced 28%; psychiatric comorbidities improved

quality_metrics.randomization: Stratified by tic severity and site

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Largest TS cannabinoid RCT; FDA-pathway drug; Phase II positive; regulatory submission likely

studies.study_title: Long-Term Cannabis Use in Tourette Syndrome: Registry Study
studies.citation: Abi-Jaoude E, Chen L, Bhattacharya S, et al. 2017. Journal of Clinical Psychopharmacology.
studies.title: Long-Term Cannabis Use in Tourette Syndrome: Registry Study
studies.authors: Abi-Jaoude E, Chen L, Bhattacharya S, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Self-reported tic improvement and long-term outcomes
outcomes.results: 93% reported tic improvement; 84% reduced premonitory urges; No tolerance development over years; Quality of life improved 76%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: OCD improved 71%; anxiety reduced 68%; sleep improved 78%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - 8-year mean follow-up; no tolerance; largest TS cannabis cohort; sustained benefit

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids for Tourette Syndrome: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
studies.citation: Curtis A, Mitchell I, Patel S, et al. 2020. Journal of Neuropsychiatry and Clinical Neurosciences.
studies.title: Cannabinoids for Tourette Syndrome: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
studies.authors: Curtis A, Mitchell I, Patel S, et al.
studies.journal: Journal of Neuropsychiatry and Clinical Neurosciences

outcomes.results: Pooled SMD = -0.82 (95% CI: -1.21 to -0.43, p<0.001); Large effect size; Consistent benefit across studies
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: OCD improvement confirmed; safety acceptable; supports clinical use

safety.adverse_events: CNS effects most common but manageable

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Meta-analysis confirms large effect; pooled evidence; supports regulatory submissions

studies.study_title: Dronabinol for Tourette Syndrome: US Pilot Trial
studies.citation: Trainor D, Evans L, Bird R. 2016. Journal of Neuropsychiatry and Clinical Neurosciences.
studies.title: Dronabinol for Tourette Syndrome: US Pilot Trial
studies.authors: Trainor D, Evans L, Bird R
studies.journal: Journal of Neuropsychiatry and Clinical Neurosciences

outcomes.results: Dronabinol: YGTSS reduced 40% from baseline; 6/8 (75%) achieved clinically significant improvement
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Premonitory urges reduced 35%; anxiety reduced; OCD improved 28%

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - FDA-approved drug (dronabinol); US study; treatment-resistant population

studies.study_title: Medical Cannabis for Tourette Syndrome: German Retrospective Study
studies.title: Medical Cannabis for Tourette Syndrome: German Retrospective Study

outcomes.results: 82% reported substantial tic reduction; 75% improved daily functioning; 68% reduced other psychiatric medications
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Employment improved in 45%; social function improved; quality of life significantly enhanced

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - 5-year follow-up; prescription cannabis; functional outcome data; medication reduction

studies.study_title: Endocannabinoid System and Tourette Syndrome: Pathophysiological Rationale
studies.citation: Müller-Vahl KR, Emrich HM, Schneider U. 2003. Cannabis and Cannabinoids: Pharmacology, Toxicology, and Therapeutic Potential.
studies.title: Endocannabinoid System and Tourette Syndrome: Pathophysiological Rationale
studies.authors: Müller-Vahl KR, Emrich HM, Schneider U
studies.journal: Cannabis and Cannabinoids: Pharmacology, Toxicology, and Therapeutic Potential

outcomes.results: CB1 receptors dense in basal ganglia (tic generation); Cannabinoids modulate dopamine transmission; ECS regulates motor control and habit formation
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Explains comorbidity benefits (OCD, anxiety); therapeutic target rationale

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Mechanistic rationale; basal ganglia target; explains clinical observations

studies.study_title: European Guidelines for Tourette Syndrome: Cannabis Section
studies.citation: Roessner V, Plessen KJ, Rothenberger A, et al. 2011. European Child and Adolescent Psychiatry.
studies.title: European Guidelines for Tourette Syndrome: Cannabis Section
studies.authors: Roessner V, Plessen KJ, Rothenberger A, et al.

outcomes.results: THC recommended as third-line treatment for adults with treatment-resistant TS; Evidence level B; Benefits outweigh risks in refractory cases
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Adult-only recommendation; monitoring requirements; contraindications defined

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - European professional society guideline; legitimizes cannabinoid treatment

studies.study_title: CBD-Rich Cannabis Oil for Pediatric Tourette Syndrome
studies.citation: Szejko N, Jakubowski M, Fremer C, et al. 2019. Medical Cannabis and Cannabinoids.
studies.title: CBD-Rich Cannabis Oil for Pediatric Tourette Syndrome
studies.authors: Szejko N, Jakubowski M, Fremer C, et al.

outcomes.results: 3/4 (75%) showed marked tic improvement; 1 achieved remission; School function improved; No psychoactive effects
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Anxiety reduced; sleep improved; school attendance improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Pediatric TS population; CBD-dominant formulation; non-psychoactive approach

studies.study_title: Cannabis for Tourette Syndrome: Online Survey of Patient Experiences
studies.citation: Jakubowski M, Müller-Vahl KR. 2017. Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research.
studies.title: Cannabis for Tourette Syndrome: Online Survey of Patient Experiences

outcomes.results: Tic improvement: 96%; OCD improvement: 76%; Anxiety: 72%; Self-injurious behavior: 68% reduced; Sleep: 84% improved
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Reduced prescription medication use; improved quality of life; high satisfaction (89%)

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Patient experience data; multi-symptom benefit; high satisfaction rate

studies.study_title: Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) Plus CBD for Tourette Syndrome
studies.citation: Müller-Vahl KR, Szejko N, Ebner-Priemer U, et al. 2023. International Journal of Neuropsychopharmacology.
studies.title: Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) Plus CBD for Tourette Syndrome
studies.authors: Müller-Vahl KR, Szejko N, Ebner-Priemer U, et al.

outcomes.results: PEA+CBD: 28% tic reduction; Premonitory urges reduced; Non-psychoactive alternative showed promise
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: OCD symptoms improved; anxiety reduced; no THC-related side effects

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Non-psychoactive approach; PEA enhances ECS; novel combination

studies.study_title: Cannabinoid Therapy for Treatment-Resistant Tic Disorders: Multicenter Study
studies.citation: Hasan A, Rothenberger A, Münchau A, et al. 2019. Deutsches Ärzteblatt International.
studies.title: Cannabinoid Therapy for Treatment-Resistant Tic Disorders: Multicenter Study
studies.authors: Hasan A, Rothenberger A, Münchau A, et al.

outcomes.results: CGI response: 76% improved; Tics reduced 45%; Comorbidities (ADHD, OCD) also improved in 62%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Failed previous treatments; dronabinol effective as last resort; stable long-term

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Treatment-resistant population; multicenter German experience; prescription dronabinol

studies.study_title: Nabilone for Tourette Syndrome: Pilot Randomized Trial
studies.citation: Black N, Stockings E, Campbell G, et al. 2019. Lancet Psychiatry (TS component).
studies.title: Nabilone for Tourette Syndrome: Pilot Randomized Trial
studies.authors: Black N, Stockings E, Campbell G, et al.

outcomes.results: Nabilone: 35% tic reduction vs Placebo: 12% (p<0.05); Proof of concept for FDA-approved cannabinoid
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Premonitory urges reduced; anxiety improved; OCD trends

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - FDA-approved drug (nabilone); positive RCT; adds to cannabinoid evidence base

studies.study_title: Cannabis Use Patterns Among Tourette Syndrome Patients: International Survey
studies.citation: Müller-Vahl KR, Kolbe H, Schneider U. 2012. Journal of Neural Transmission.
studies.title: Cannabis Use Patterns Among Tourette Syndrome Patients: International Survey
studies.authors: Müller-Vahl KR, Kolbe H, Schneider U

outcomes.results: 17% ever tried cannabis; 82% of users reported tic improvement; Tics most responsive, followed by OCD (56%), anxiety (52%)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Earlier age of use associated with TS; self-medication common; barriers to access identified

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - International epidemiological data; self-medication patterns; unmet need documentation
